abstract: Trading results are good place to start when assessing whether banks release sufficient information about their financial results.
snippet: Trading results are good place to start when assessing whether banks release sufficient information about their financial results.
lead_paragraph: Traders at the top Wall Street firms racked up nearly $80 billion of revenue last year. But understanding how they produced all that money is far from simple.

headline.main: Making Sense of Wall Street’s Trading Revenue

abstract: If the financial crisis made anything clear, the author contends, it’s that banks should be forced to defend their business models and corporate governance — regularly.
snippet: If the financial crisis made anything clear, the author contends, it’s that banks should be forced to defend their business models and corporate governance — regularly.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street has found a new way to put shareholders second. Many banks are finally bowing to pressure to restrain compensation, but Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are now trying to stifle investors from voting on legitimate matters at their upcoming annual meetings.

headline.main: On Wall Street, Putting Shareholders Second

abstract: JPMorgan Chase’s chief risk officer is taking a temporary sabbatical, the latest move in an extensive reshuffling of JPMorgan’s executive suite after a botched credit bet that has cost the bank more than $6 billion.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase’s chief risk officer is taking a temporary sabbatical, the latest move in an extensive reshuffling of JPMorgan’s executive suite after a botched credit bet that has cost the bank more than $6 billion.

headline.main: Amid a Shake-Up, JPMorgan’s Risk Officer Takes a Leave
headline.print_headline: JPMorgan’s Risk Officer Takes a Leave
